channel.description: The recognition of a need for authentication is not new to the web - itâ€™s been there since the earliest standards. In fact, the original URL specification included an optional username and password as part of its format (specified as [username]:[password]@ between the protocol and host). I.e. to make a HTTP authenticated request against the CS departmental server you might use: https://willie:purpleandwhite@cs.ksu.edu/ However, the use of authentication URLS is now highly discouraged and has been stripped from most browsers, as it is considered a security risk. Instead, if you are using HTTP-based authentication the server needs to issue a challenge 401 Unauthorized response, along with a WWW-Authenticate header specifying the challenge.
